BIG 5 PERSONALITY QUESTIONAIRE: By answering all the questions in this document, you will be able to get an approximate reading of where you stand on each of the Big 5 personality traits.
Each section will have a header explaining that section, and then many questions or ideas for which you should rate yourself, typically on a 1-5 or 1-7 scale.
Following is an example question. Suppose that it is on a  1-5 scale, with 5 meaning "Strongly agree"
Example statement: I am looking at the big 5 personality questionaire

0 or a for the first choice - 1 or b for the second choice
Persons’ actions should be described in terms of (a. good or bad.) (b. right or wrong.)
The aim of science should be (a. to solve existing problems.) (b. discover truth.)
Solutions to ethical problems are usually (a. some shade of gray.) (b. black and white.)
When thinking through ethical problems, I prefer to (a. think up practical, workable alternatives.) (b. make reasonable distinctions and clarifications.)
It is more important to be (a. happy.) (b. worthy.)
I would prefer to be perceived as being (a. open minded, tolerant, and accepting.) (b. discerning and perceptive.)
The purpose of government should be (a. to promote the best possible life for its citizens.) (b. to secure justice and fair treatment.)
Whether a person is a liar is (a. a matter of degree.) (b. a question of kind.  )
Uttering a falsehood is wrong because (a. it wouldn’t be right for anyone to lie.) (b. depending on the results, it can lead to further problems.)
When making an ethical decision, one should pay attention to (a. one’s conscience.) (b. others’ needs, wants, and desires.)
A nation should pay more attention to (a. its heritage, its roots.) (b. its future, its potential.)
It is of more value to societies to (a. follow stable traditions and maintain a distinct identity.) (b. be responsive and adapt to new conditions as the world changes.)
When people disagree over ethical matters, I strive for (a. some point(s) of agreement.) (b. workable compromises.)
Unethical behavior is best described as (a. violation of principle or law.) (b. causing some degree of harm.)
Thinking of occupations, I would rather be a (a. wise judge, applying the law with fairness and impartiality.) (b. benevolent legislator, seeking an improved life for all.)
